Baghdad July 10
Darling Mother, I 've got your letter of June 8
+ also the Heart of Yorkshir + I must write
specialy to tell you hour charming I think
the play. It' s fall of poetry + grave,
how
acted in its our setting it ought to have
a tremendous effect. The sentiment of it
is so delicious. How pretty the costumers
will be, + the little modern seeme will
only empleasize them. But final allegorny
is the crown of it all - I do think
its so good.
doesnt it seem a pity that
I shant see it
We' re having an interesting time too as you 'le
see in my letter to Father. I' me sure we' be
done the right thing, but there have been
momeets of great anxiety, + but for Sir
Percy we should never have succeeded.
once we' be got Faisal onto his throne which
might almost be in the next fortnight he be
gradually take charge himself, I hope.
But upon my soul he has got a difficult.

task before him + what amazes me is
that he should want to be King of Iraq
However it' s a mercy that he does
I need not say that I shall not go
to India this sumoner. You very
well - I content leave at this
junctur
Ever your very affectionate +
admiriny daughter

Aug 28 1921
Dearest Mother, I must send you
a particular word to tell you
how delighted, I was to get
your accounts of the Heart of
Yorkshin + the newepaper
enttings. It must have been
wonderful - the most
beautiful thing you' be ever
done. If I weren' t so
dreadfully recepied in
making kings + governments
I should be lost in rgret
+that I warn' t there. Anyway
3
am most delighted you
brought it off so brithantly
Father saysit was lovely.

I am now longing to get
your first, ansevers to my
Fensal letters. I feel quite
certain you ill be thrilted
our cant help it
even if the accounts I
give you are very crude
written at racing spend
on a Sunday, morning
I' me glad I' be teved to
take part in this thing +
as far as I can to
Meord it. My letter to
you are the only private

record but I write the officers
reports which are, not
without interest
You know the Naqih has
got the 913 C. he s
immensely pleased. I
think Father might
some time write to Faisal
- in English - a
tell him, he is pleased
+ all. We will have
him to stay at Rton if
he comes to England next
Summer as he talks
of drug. He 's a great dear

You haven' t said anything
about Hugo 's engagement. I
hope you like her + that

His letter to me makes
me feel it 's very satisfactory
but I shall long to hear
that you think of her
Your account of the Trevelyan,
+ Rechmond children is
delightful - it will be
nice having another family
now wont it;
what a good place to do the

don' t see why it shouldn 't

when I come back next
year.

curious existence, but
don 't count for nearly as

is out I who sittles policy.
nor anyone but Sir Percy

no people likes permanently to be
governed by another. Last year when they were
all erying for Abdullah it wasnt for his

thought the any was ant- British. I perceived

'Abdullah would never dream. of coming if he
were not assured of British support - which
was true - but I always felt that it was

we' re trying to froter

Baghdad Time 12 Received fire 21 th 1921
192
Dearist Father. There has been no mail this
all
a week - confound all postmen. It has also been rather
a tiresome week because of the Feast of Baiian, the 3 days
feust at the end of Ramadhan. We contrived to spread it out to by days,
for this reason - the calendar new moon was on Monday, but Mondery
evening was clondy + 'me persuaded no our saw the duvon. The
sums however pretended they did + breakfasted" as it' s called
The She 'ahs with a wildig are declared they weren' t satisped +
did not breakfast. So their feast went on till Friday + since
it was Fridiy + the Shilahs were still feasting, no due did
any work. Mr Gurbett + I paid a lot of congrabulatory calls
on Talrday, beginning with the Naqab at 7 a. M. I said I hoped
we hadn' t come too early. "of no" he rephed" I' ve been
receiving visitors since dawn. They are rather jerurn occasion
these 'd visits (Ids Feast). You eat sircctmeats +
druch coffec + sherbet, with an inward hope that the latter
maynt be fall of typlrs gernes. And you carry on a colousless
conversation - at least I did, for I did not wish to
embark on controversial politics. The Naqib sent you many
messages as he always does. I paid more calls by myself
in the afternoon, but next day I confined myself to a
before - breakfast call on Haji Naji who as a She' ah
had just breakfasted. On Thursday I called on some
She 'an Ministers + also on the balance of the Naqih family
who all two in a quarter just behind my house. The
eldest son of the Naqib, Saiyid Muhmud. I found holding
his levee in a diwar inside the sacred precients of
the Gadmigah shrine, the burial place of his ancstor
'Abdul Gadir. So I joined the company of Surin
dostors + we talked of - the breeds of 'Arab horses +
of how, peentrarly beneficent to the horse are the waters

of Euphrates
Things are at last beginning to more. Telegrams
have come from King Husain saying that Faisal
leaves forthe 'Iraq this week - a fact of
3
which we were already aware. we now have to prefare
the way for him. An inspired Reater is to be sent,
from home tomorro + next day Mr Churchill makes
a statement on lines suggested by Sir Percy. After
that Sir Percy will have a heart to heart talk with
the Naqib + advise him as a friend, not to come
forward as a candidate on account of his great age.
The Shaikh of Muhammarah, by the bye, has
already with drawn.
what everybody wants is to know our wishes + be
ginded by them + as soon, as they get any kind of lead
they will all. I think, come into line. Meantime, in
my sole as the Nabi 'Isa, I receive many agitated
visits from my young Shanfian friends, asking for
reassmances + for guidance, which I give to the
best of my ability + according to Sir Percy 's directions.
He is a master hand at the game of polities; its
an education to watch him, playing it.
I told you about Marie 's falling off a pony.
she didn' t seem to get any less lame so finally
we had her prayed + found that she had
cracked a bone. 's not serious + will.
probably be better in another fortnight, only she

is told to walk as little as possible - she heed not
go completely to bed.
to my relief. It 's very booing
for her, poor thing
I' ve just had this Sundery morning a long visit
from X big shenkhs, + Fahad Beg of the 'Anizah
I the giver of my days) +a 'All Sulaiman, of the
Dulaim. Both came down from Ramadi to
see Sir Percy + find out his views. They have
hitherits been running a campengh on behalf
of the Naqil, on the ground that they are
perfectly content under our administration +
know the Naqib to be entirely subenissive to
Sir Percy 's wishes. So they have been told
to stay here for a day or two, when H. M. G.
will make pronouncements
I don 't for a moment hesitate about the
lightness of our policy. We can 't contimederet
British control though, the country would be
better governed under it, but it 's rather
a comie position to be telling people
over + over again that whether they like
it or not they must have Arab, not
British Govt.
At the back of my mind there' s the firm

to the Comal, who stopped me + told me this excellent new
I rode on much cheered + when I got home found a letter
from Sir Percy enclosing the long- expected communicate
which he told me to get through to Jafar or Najs
Suwaidi before the meeting which was to take place
at 8 next morning. By good much Je' far with his wife
+ Sister were dining so I translated the commnnigue
to them + gave it to Ja' far for the meeting. They
were all delighted with it + indeed it was
just what we wanted
Next day Naji Suwaidi, + the Mutasarrif, Rashed
Bag, came to my office after the meeting to report.
It had been a great success; everyone had been
present + 60 people had been chosen to go down
to Busrah to welcome Faisal - would. I kindly
make arrangements with the Failway. There remained
the question of his lodging here which I they proposed to
solve by putting him into some rooms, in the Sarai
(the Government offices) which were now under repair
They included the old Tarkish Comail chamber + seemed
to be quite suitable, if they could be got ready in
time. Public works declared at first that it couldn' t
be done. Ja' far telephoned to me in despan on sat.
morning; I telephoned to public works, made suggestions
for covering bare walls with hangings + fincelly the
thing was arranged
In the evening I went to the Nabib, whom I found
receiving the report of the Reception Committee. Direitly
I got in he showed me a telegrai which had just
come to him from King Husain conched in very sentable.

Baghdad June 19. Received fairly 21. 1921
1921
Dearest Father. These have been 2 mails this week
the bringing your letters of May + 1 but oodly enough
nothing from Mother. Munear It' s put an accident or
She may have been unnsually busy. I return you the mens about
by incouetax filled in to the best of my ability. As far as
know the India office was still paying us lep to As 4
financial
but possibly the last month of the': year may have been
on the charge of the Middle Eastern Sept of the Colonial
office. The letter of Lord Aslifield in the times is an
excellent + tuuety contribuition to the controversy. Itematel
the arguments he use must prevail because they are parts
from which you can' t escape. The whole question is whether
people will Meeoginge + how to them in time or will wast
till disaster forces the recoguition of them. Isht that it. I
gather from Renters that the immediate struggle to coming
to an end. What you say about the supineness of the public
is very curious, but at any rate there has been nothing which
looks like social upheaval or be class bitterness
We here are now launched on our perilous way On Monday
by old friend the Major, Abdul Majid Shawi - we had tea with him
just before you left, you remember - came to my office + said that
since Farsal was coming it was up to the Notables of Baghdad
to make a proper reception for him + not to leave it all to the
young extremests - of whom the notables are very fealonus. Taisal
was a fumous Arab + the son of a King + must be treated.
as such. I said I thought that view perfictly proper, he as the
Major of the town should make the arrangements. There followed
him Naji Suwaidi, who is the leading man of the younger group.
+ I begged him to take advantage of Abdul Majid' s attitude +
let the older men assume the lead because they were the people
to conciliate. He promised to do so but I don 't think the relations

work out quite happily. It' s a matter which needs being
careful watching + any help one can discreetly give it.
The younger men have frequented my office this
week. We had to settle on a temporary flag - I to
suppose the Constituent Assemble will have the final word there
+ then there was the difficult question as to where Fuisal
should be lodged. If only we had got the official commussiaut
from home earher everything looked have been much case
We should have been able to give a more decided had to
the people + a more decided warmn to our own officers
As it was our friends here of the Abdal Majid tyfe were
always trying to find out what the British Govt really
wanted + we couldn' t in plain words tell than, while
our officers were advicating tacitly or openly, that the
final decision as to the sovereign should be put off for
a term of years or that we should begin with a
Republic so as to let the country find itself - nerther of
which propositions would the home Govt take on. The Govt
is right I think because the country wont find itself till
we give it a lead, postponement only means continual
discontent, on the part of the Nationalists + resulting intrigue
+ as for a sepublic we' de not reached the stage of
political equilibrinon at which. We could contemphate
with equaninnity the periodical, upheaval of a
presidential election. It 's true however that we' re gentle
pushing the country into a Nationalist hath which
at this moment it doesnt vices with much favour.
The point of vicer of the Nuqib + his group must be
sympatheticaly considered. Their argument is that they
witnessed the young extremests make a Mess of Synia
+ they don 't want a repitition of those events here. They
disapproved of the rebection last year + now they see the

very, men who organized it all pardoned under the amnesty
+ presumably coming back with Farsal to beast that in
the end they have worn + to take the top places. That
their openly expressed fear + it' s a thing we must do
our utmost not to allow. I believe Faisal is states man
enough to realize that he must capture a relyapon
the older more steady going people wikite at the Same
time not chilling overmuch the enthersiasin of his more ardent
supporters
well to contine my talk. Time was as Mips Thomson used to
say force. Here was Feisal arriving at Basrah on the 2910 +
we still without any comuiniqne from home. We had actually
never said officially that he was arriving But his
partisans were growing naturally upatient + anxious to get.
busy. Sir Percy realized this, + unofficialy approved the
project presented through me - in my capacity as the Nabi
Isle, you understand - that they should summon the town
to a big meeting on Friday, 6 days before Faisal 's arrival
As soon as the mortations were out in the name of Naji
Sewend. bisteops + others droffed in to my office to some
me as to whether they, ought to go. on yes said I
"why not? the meeting has the approval of H. C. "On
Thursday afternoon the Naqib, like the old gentleman he
is, made a sound more. He informed the Counal of
Ministers that Faisal was coming + that they must
make preparations to receive him properly + see that he
was sentably lodged. Thereupon they appointed a reception
committee of to Ministers including 'Abdul Majid +
a 'far Pasha. I had been out riding after tea + on
I met Saiyid HusaniAfnan the secretary
the was teoul

river by lanch, with Mr Tod + a party, to swine.
We take dinner with us + at it on the
way back - he provided the douchs + I the
food
Every. beloved family your very affectinate

Gertrude

terms + announcing that he was sulding
his son Faisal to him. I was' t as much
surprised as I might have been for we
and
had ugently telegraphed in the beginning.
of the week to say that Husain must send some
message of this kind to the Naqib. The Naqib
their lead me his refly drafted by Saiyid Haisan
what. he said, what? peerng at it. + then
took a pen + cut out some of the honorifics which
daiyed Husain, had thought fit to prefix to the King 's
name. However He left quite enough + we all
expressed our approval
This morning, being Sunday. Mr Tod + I rode before
brenhfast to Haji Maji whom we found setting
with an old Saiyid of Karradah who is rather
a friend of mine. Haji Naji presently drew me aside +
told me he thought of going with the party to Busrah
only he was rather afraid of being lost in the much.
I said I would give him a letter of intirduction
to Mr Cornwallis who is coming with Faisal to
that be might be treated with consideration This
entirely satisfied him, + we returned to the
Summer house to eat the excellent apriests +
applies which he set before us. Finally I sent
for 'Abdul Rajid Shawi + Fakhri Jamil, + had
a long heart to heart talk with them - they are
both on the Naqib 's Reception Committee. They seem
quite happy so I hope things are going well. Theyrijust left.
By the way I must tell you that be Friday morning

Taji Naji also came to my office after the meeting
as good much would have it your cleppers
arrived just at that moment. So we opened
+ admired them + Haji Naji observed conversationlly.
to the others per + whenever her Father goes to
London he sends me a present. He was very
much delighted + the fact that the geft was
made before others, was all to the good.
Fakhri Jamil begs me to say to you that he
sent you his photograph but you haven' t sent
him yours in return
In the + middle of all these absorbing events I went
to a balt given by the Thillys at the Club+ I didn'
dance but I' set out in theagarden, + called to
lots of people + I was passably amassed but I feet
too full of other things to be able to give, much
attention to balls. It 's a perfect mania here backs
Thever go but they danger at the Club, 3 or 4
times a week. Its accused, I think. Men who
are as hard workedg as our officials can' set
up till one or two, the the moving + be in their
offices at 7 or it. It 's the wives that do it
confound them. they take no sort of interest in
what' s going on, know no Aralic + the, no Arabs
They create an exclusive ( though it by alsogvery
second rate) English society, quite out off from the

our women do just
